name.text: 25.3.3.2 Method of separation of variables - specific solutions

questiontext.text:
Example

Solve the \(1\)-dimensional wave equation \(\quad\displaystyle \dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}=\dfrac{1}{16}\dfrac{\partial^2u}{\partial t^2}\)   for \(0<x<2,\ \ \ t>0\)

The boundary conditions are

\(\qquad\displaystyle u(0,t)=u(2,t)=0\)

The initial conditions are

(i)  \(u(x,0)=6\sin\pi x-3\sin 4\pi x\) \(\qquad\qquad\)(ii)   \(\dfrac{\partial u}{\partial t}(x,0)=0\)

  1. Firstly, either using \((7)\) and \((8)\) or by working from first principles assuming the product solution

    \(\qquad u(x,t)=X(x)T(t),\)

    write down the ODEs satisfied by \(X(x)\) and \(T(t)\):
  2. Now decide on the appropriate sign for \(K\) and then write down the solution to these equations:
  3. Now obtain the general solution \(u(x,t)\) by multiplying \(X(x)\) by \(T(t)\) and insert the two boundary conditions to obtain information about two of the constants:
  4. Now insert the initial condition

    \(\qquad\displaystyle \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial t}(x,0)=0\ \ \text{for all}\ x\qquad 0<x<2.\)

    and deduce the value of \(F\):
  5. Finally using the other the initial condition  \(u(x,0)=6\sin(\pi x)-3\sin (4\pi x)\) deduce the form of \(u(x,t)\):

Solution

  1. \(\dfrac{X''}{X}=K \qquad\qquad \dfrac{T''}{16T}=K\)
  2. Choosing \(K\) as negative (say \(K = −\lambda^2)\) will produce Sinusoidal solutions for \(X\) and \(T\) which are appropriate in the context of the wave equation where oscillatory solutions can be expected.
    Then \(X'' = −\lambda^2 X\) gives
    \(\qquad X = A\cos\lambda x + B\sin\lambda x\)
    Similarly \(T'' = −16\lambda^2 T\) gives
    \(\qquad T = C\cos4\lambda t + D\sin4\lambda t\)

  3. \(u(x, t) = (A\cos\lambda x + B\sin\lambda x)(C\cos4\lambda t + D\sin4\lambda t)\)

    \(u(0, t) = 0\) for all \(t\) gives

    \(\qquad A(C\cos4\lambda t + D\sin4\lambda t) = 0\)

    which implies that \(A = 0\).

    \(u(2, t) = 0\) for all \(t\) gives

    \(\qquad B\sin2\lambda (C\cos4\lambda t + D\sin4\lambda t) = 0\)

    so, for a non-trivial solution,

    \(\qquad \sin2\lambda = 0 \qquad \) i.e. \(\qquad \lambda = \dfrac{n\pi}{2}\) for some integer \(n\).

    At this stage we write the solution as

    \(\qquad u(x, t) = \sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2} \right) (E\cos2n\pi t + F\sin2n\pi t)\)

    where we have multiplied constants and put \(E = BC\) and \(F = BD\).
  4. Differentiating partially with respect to \(t\)

    \(\qquad \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2}\right)(−2n\pi E \sin 2n\pi t + 2n\pi F\cos 2n\pi t)\)

    so at \(t = 0\)

    \(\qquad \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial t}(x,0) = \sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2}\right)2n\pi F = 0\)

    from which we must have that \(F = 0\).
  5. At this stage the solution reads
    \(\qquad u(x, t) = E\sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2}\right)\cos(2n\pi t)\) \((12)\)
    We now have to insert the last condition i.e. the initial condition
    \(\qquad u(x, 0) = 6\sin \pi x − 3 \sin 4\pi x\) \((13)\)
    This seems strange because, putting \(t = 0\) in our solution \((12)\) suggests

    \(\qquad u(x, 0) = E \sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2}\right)\)

    At this point we seem to have incompatability because no single value of \(n\) will enable us to satisfy \((13)\). However, in the solution \((12)\), any positive integer value of \(n\) is acceptable and we can in fact, superpose solutions of the form (\(12)\) and still have a valid solution to the PDE Hence we first write, instead of \((12)\)
    \(\qquad u(x, t) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty E_n\sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2}\right)\cos(2n\pi t)\) \[(14)\]
    from which
    \(\qquad u(x, 0) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty E_n\sin\left(\dfrac{n\pi x}{2}\right)\) \[(15)\]

    (which looks very much like, and indeed is, a Fourier series.)


    To make the solution \((15)\) fit the initial condition \((13)\) we do not require all the terms in the infinite Fourier series. We need only the terms with \(n = 2\) with coefficient \(E_2 = 6\) and the term for which \(n = 8\) with \(E_8 = −3\). All the other coefficients \(E_n\) have to be chosen as zero.

    Using these results in \((14)\) we obtain the solution

    \(\qquad u(x, t) = 6 \sin \pi x \cos 4\pi t − 3 \sin 4\pi x \cos 16\pi t\)

The above solution perhaps seems rather involved but there is a definite sequence of logical steps which can be readily applied to other similar problems.
